techniques.comment: The malware appears to deobfuscate information during its execution to evade detection and carry out its malicious activities.
The malware uses encryption to pack its payload and avoid detection.
The malware uses data obfuscation to pack its payload, making it more difficult to interpret the software's malicious actions.
Sometimes it is seen that the malware is looking for some specific files or directories when infecting a machine.
The malware relies on API Hooking, attaching its payload to a particular function's API calls to ensure that it runs each time that function is invoked.
The original malware payload is packed or compressed, presumably to make it easier to deliver to the targeted systems.
StrelaStealer uses software packing to obfuscate its code, making it harder for security tools to detect its malicious functions.
The malware appears to inject its malicious code into other processes to execute its payload and potentially elevate its access privileges in the process.
